title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State establishes a Board of Visa Appeals composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, petitions, and waivers of inadmissibility. If the Board finds a decision contrary to the evidence, it can overrule or remand it for further consideration. The Board of Visa Appeals can review decisions made by consular officers based on evidence presented, and has the authority to overrule or remand decisions if they are contrary to the evidence. Proceedings before the Board must follow regulations set by the Secretary of State, ensuring that all parties involved are notified of the review process and have access to the necessary steps for requesting a review. The interested party shall be notified of the review process and steps to request it. A written record of the proceedings and decision shall be available to the Board and the alien. The Board must notify the consular officer and receive the record within 30 days of a review request. The appellant must be given notice of the Board proceedings and can be represented by counsel at no cost to the Government. The Board reviews decisions upon request of the alien or interested parties such as petitioners of immigrant or nonimmigrant visa petitions. A written request for review must be made within 60 days of notice of denial, revocation, or cancellation. Appellants can be represented by counsel at no cost to the Government. The review is limited to once in a 24-month period and does not restrict certain entities from seeking review. The Board of Visa Appeals in the United States allows for a review of decisions regarding employment offers to aliens for executive or supervisory roles. Requests for review can only be made once every 24 months and a fee is charged for the review process. Effective dates for the amendment are specified in the legislation. The Act specifies timelines for regulations and appointments related to visa appeals. Technical amendments are made to sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act.
